Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Parallel and non-parallel evolution at multiple levels: environment, selection, phenotype, and genotype
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental puzzle in evolutionary biology is whether evolution is repeatable: if many identical starting populations were exposed to the same type of novel environment, would they all evolve the same adaptations? Would the adaptations result from changes in the same underlying genes? This research project aims to answer both questions using a small fish, the threespine stickleback, as a study subject. The same ocean-dwelling form of stickleback colonized many separate river basins when the glaciers melted ~12,000 years ago, providing a naturally occurring experiment to test the repeatability of evolution. The researchers will measure environmental, morphological, and genetic divergence between adjacent lake and stream populations of stickleback, from each of 16 watersheds that represent separate instances of evolved lake-stream differences. They will then apply state-of-the-art statistical analyses to measure the extent to which differences between lake and stream types have evolved repeatedly or are unique to each watershed. Genetic analysis will reveal the extent to which repeated morphological differences result from evolutionary changes in the same genes.

The project will reveal general principles of how predictable evolutionary change is, and pioneer relevant statistical methods. Such principles and methods are vital to anticipating how pests or diseases may evolve in response to pesticides or drugs, or how species will adapt to climate change. In addition, the project will pair up leading biological researchers with high-school biology teachers and pre-service teachers-in-training, giving K-12 science teachers practical research experience involving fundamental principles of evolutionary biology.

Award Title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Parallel and non-parallel evolution at multiple levels: environment, selection, phenotype, and genotype

Federal Award ID: 1144773

 

Project Outcomes Report

 

Context:

How repeatable is evolution? If we were to allow evolution to replay many times, would we get the same result every time? If not, why not? Can we explain when and why evolution yields different outcomes, even in populations faced with similar challenges? Our research sought to answer these questions by examining the outcome of repeated, or parallel evolution. A small fish, threespine stickleback, are originally ocean-dwelling but some colonized freshwater habitats in the Pacific Northwest after ice-age glaciers retreated 12,000 years ago. Every river basin was separately colonized. So, the subsequent adaptation to freshwater lakes or streams represents an independent instance of evolutionary adaptation. Rather than replaying evolution, we are taking advantage of a case where many separate instances of evolution happened simultaneously. 

We collected fish specimens from 16 lakes, paired with 16 adjacent streams, and measured environmental, genomic, and phenotypic data from the resident fish. The resulting data allowed us to ask, how repeatable was evolution? Did the evolution of lake versus stream fish over the past 12,000 years lead to the same lake-stream differences in each of the 16 separate watersheds? Or, did different lake-stream pairs diverge in unique ways? If so, can we use environmental or genomic data to predict such non-repeated evolution?

 

Findings:

We discovered that most of the 86 morphological traits that we measured evolve non-repeatably. That is, sometimes the trait is exaggerated in a lake relative to its stream neighbors, and sometimes exaggerated in a stream relative to lake neighbors. Only a few traits were highly repeatable. This runs counter to a wide perception among evolutionary biologists that sticklebacks’ recent evolution is highly repeatable. In fact, the previous focus on parallel evolution is because researchers cherry-picked the most dramatically parallel traits. The reality is far more complicated – and interesting.

            Next, we tested whether environmental or genomic data allow us to explain the non-parallelism. As we initially hypothesized, some lake-stream pairs differ in the same way as other lake-stream pairs (same traits diverge, in the same direction and magnitude). These tend to involve lakes and streams that differ in the same ecological variables. But, not all lakes (or, streams) are identical. Among-lake and among-stream variation in ecological factors allows us to predict which watersheds are exceptions to the rule, showing less repeatable evolution.

 

Intellectual Merit: We discovered that we can predict when repeated cases of evolution will yield similar or dissimilar results. Ecological data help us predict which traits will or will not evolve in a repeatable manner. Neutral genomic data help us predict the magnitude of divergence in traits (due to constraining effects of migration between habitats). This predictive power suggests that evolution (even non-repeated evolution) may be more predictable than we previously thought. And this ability to predict the outcome of evolution is essential if we are to build tools to anticipate the outcome of evolution in response to global change.

 

Broader Impacts

 

The completed project provided research experience and training for 18 undergraduate students, 4 PhD students, and 5 K-12 STEM teachers, and 2 technicians, many of whom are co-authors or first authors on one or more scientific articles.
